results.title: The Australian Constitution (A)
results.creator_credit: Jane Innes and University of Wollongong
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Millenium Dilemma: Constitutional Change in Australia”.
This first episode in the “Millennium dilemma” series introduces the study of the Australian Constitution through discussion of its historical foundations and development. At the opening of the program questions are put forward such as what does the Australian Constitution do? Where does the Australian Constitution come from? Does it reflect reality? Where do Indigenous people fare in the Australian Constitution? This is followed by a responsive commentary from a range of contributors on these subjects. These interviewees include politicians, political analysts, media commentators, academics and legal counsel such as Professor Tony Blackshield, Sir Zelman Cowan QC, Chief Justice of NSW Murray Gleeson, Professor Stuart Macintyre, Senate Clerk Harry Evans, Kristen Walker, Anne Mullins and Hugh Mackay.

results.title: The Australian Bicentennial Golf Classic
results.brief_description: The prestigious and classic Australian golfing event, held at the Royal Melbourne Golf course, is one of Australia’s most important Bicentennial sports event. A sensational field of competitors compete for the highest prize money ever offered in an Australian golfing event. The world’s number one golfer, and one of Australia’s greatest sportsmen, Greg Norman, pairs head to head against “Golfer of the Century” Jack Nicklaus. Includes Roger Davis, Nick Faldo and many more of golf’s champion players.

results.title: The Australian ballet: opening act 1962-1972
results.creator_credit: Michelle Potter, Sally Jackson, National Library of Australia and ScreenSound Australia
results.brief_description: It was a fortuitous evening when Harold Holt, then federal treasurer, approached Peggy van Praagh and advised her the he could provide the financial means to establish what would become Australia’s first national ballet company. The season opened in 1962 with a performance of Swan Lake at Her Majesty’s Theatre in Sydney and featured 40 dancers, chiefly comprised from the Borovansky ballet company, that van Praagh took over on the death of its titular founder. The company toured Australia, introducing delighted audiences to the classics, innovative pieces and new choreography including Melbourne Cup, and The Display and Yugen by Sir Robert Helpmann who would later join van Praagh as co-artistic director. Helpmann and van Praag represented two sides of the artistic coin - Helpmann a flamboyant promoter of the ballet without being actively involved in the day to day running, and van Praag, the English teacher and educator who maintained a strong bond between the company and her mother country. Introduced by Barry Kitcher and narrated by Helen Vaughan Roberts, this program presents archival footage of performances, highlights of international guests such as Sonia Arova, Erik Bruhn, Margot Fonteyn and Rudolf Nureyev, original pieces from the 1950s, biographical information about Helpmann and van Praag and profiles Australian artists including Marilyn Rowe and Kelvin Coe.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michelle Potter, Sally Jackson, National Library of Australia and ScreenSound Australia

results.title: The Australian Ballet - Corroboree
results.brief_description: ‘Corroboree’ is both a record of the world premiere of the famous Australian ballet, and a behind-the-scenes glimpse of the rehearsal, design and preparation that went into the production. Inspired by composer John Antill’s best known work, the ballet was sponsored by the Arts Council of Australia and choreographed by Rex Reid. Performed by the National Theatre Ballet Company and the Sydney Symphony Orchestra, ‘Corroboree’ is a striking illustration of some of the ways in which white Australia has imagined and expropriated Australian First Nations cultures.

results.title: The Australian Alps: Mirka's Palace of Dreams (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: David Greig, David Morgan and Kestrel Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Australian wilderness series”.
This program is the last in a series of six documentaries that examine the wilderness areas of Australia. Mirka Mora is an eccentric artist, French by birth, who had never before ventured into the wilderness nor slept in a tent. Along with Tim McCartney Snape, the first Australian ever to reach the summit of Mt. Everest, and a Nepalese Sherpa, she travels into the Kosciusko wilderness. Mirka’s unique and expressive personality helps viewers see and experience this wilderness from an artist’s perspective.

results.title: The Australian airman: 1939-1945
results.creator_credit: Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “War Experience”.
The men who served in the Royal Australian Air Force during the Second World War. At first it was a European war - over Germany, France, and Italy, but then the allies were driven back over North Africa. The Japanese aggression brought the men back to Australian shores and Pacific islands. Joining the Air Force with a spirit of adventure, the close of the war saw broken spirits and mental and physical suffering.

results.title: The Australian AIDS tape
results.creator_credit: Nick Torrens, Sabina Wynn, Health Media and Education Centre and New South Wales. Dept. of Health
results.brief_description: Aimed at the general community and provides factual information about AIDS. What HIV/AIDS is. How HIV is transmitted. How HIV is not transmitted. How to prevent it. What to do if you are worried. Offers a telephone number in each State which people can call for further information. A current affair style approach with animation and graphics is used. It was developed for use by educators but can stand alone as an educational resource if no AIDS educator is available. Presented by Geraldine Doogue.
